citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
- An elderly male buffalo is extremely thin and muscle wasted. He was observed by inspectors showing some reluctance
to stand from a sternal position when offered feed by the facility. This animal has not been evaluated by a veterinarian to
assess his health and condition. Significant weight loss in an older animal could be due to many different problems,
ranging from internal illness to a reluctance to compete for food with other animals. Exhibitors must establish and maintain
programs of adequate veterinary care that provide appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases
and injuries to protect the health and welfare of animals housed in the facility. This buffalo must be evaluated by a
licensed veterinarian within 5 business days and treated in an appropriate manner depending on the recommendation of
the veterinarian.
Correct by 26 April 2025

- The enclosure fence for the male camel is sagging and loose in multiple locations. There are signs that the camel has
been rubbing on part of the fence. The current fence is an ineffective enclosure barrier and is also a risk of injury or
entrapment to the animal. Outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to contain
and protect animals from injury. The facility must repair or replace the fencing in order to safely contain and protect the
camel.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
- An elderly male buffalo is extremely thin and muscle wasted. He was observed by inspectors showing some reluctance 
to stand from a sternal position when offered feed by the facility. This animal has not been evaluated by a veterinarian to 
assess his health and condition. Significant weight loss in an older animal could be due to many different problems, 
ranging from internal illness to a reluctance to compete for food with other animals. Exhibitors must establish and maintain 
programs of adequate veterinary care that provide appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases 
and injuries to protect the health and welfare of animals housed in the facility. This buffalo must be evaluated by a 
licensed veterinarian within 5 business days and treated in an appropriate manner depending on the recommendation of 
the veterinarian. 
Correct by 26 April 2025 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
- The enclosure fence for the male camel is sagging and loose in multiple locations. There are signs that the camel has 
been rubbing on part of the fence. The current fence is an ineffective enclosure barrier and is also a risk of injury or 
entrapment to the animal. Outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to contain 
and protect animals from injury. The facility must repair or replace the fencing in order to safely contain and protect the 
camel. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: GRAY WOLF / GREY WOLF / TIMBER WOLF
